meta.field: nasalization property of morpheme or syllable
vs. nasalization as property of segments
nasal spreading across some morpheme boundaries
do some affixes or other morphemes take the nasal/oral properties of the root they attach to?
(onset consists of more than one consonant phoneme)

data.field: complex segments exist, but no clusters of segments
nasal segments are allophones of voiced stops
for certain suffixes only, and within words that are historically bi-morphemic but relexicalized.

meta.field: number of prefixes is roughly equal to or greater than number of suffixes
derivational morphology on verbs is only suffixal
derivational morphology on verbs is only prefixal
number of applicatives in the language
applicative adds a beneficiary object argument to the verb
applicative adds a negatively-affected object argument to the verb; may be same as benefactive applic
applicative adds an instrumental object argument to the verb
applicative adds a goal object argument to the verb
derives a transitive verb from an intransitive verb
any other applicatives which are not detailed above
for causatives formed via serial/compound verb constructions, see analytical causative (below)
causative is morphological and is attached before the root of the verb
causative is morphological and is attached after the root of the verb
causative is morphological and is in two parts, one which occurs before the root of the verb and one which occurs after the root of the verb
indicates that the causer does not directly cause the action of the verb to be realized, but does so by inducing someone else to carry out the action, e.g. 'John had the house painted.'
indicates that causer participates in event
Derives a verb which indicates the reversal of the action denoted by the underived verb, e.g. 'zip' and 'un-zip'.
indicates that the subject desires to carry out the action denoted by the verb (distinct from verb 'want', but may be grammaticalized from it)
Passive voice is formed by a morpheme attached to the verb stem; the object of the active voice verb is promoted to subject in the passive voice.
verb becomes reflexive through use of reflexive morpheme attached to verb. This morpheme is used only to mean reflexive.
verb becomes reciprocal through use of reciprocal morpheme attached to the verb root. This morpheme is only used to mean reciprocal
verb becomes reciprocal or reflexive through use of a morpheme that means either reciprocal or reflexive which attaches to the root of the verb

data.field: very marginal; reflex morpheme can occasionally have a reciprocal interpretation

meta.field: derives an intransitive verb from a transitive one
unpossessed derivational affix for inalienable nouns
An inalienable noun that is in an unpossessed state must have a derivational affix
possessive suffix with possessed alienable NPs
A possessed alienable noun phrase contains a possessive suffix
Default possessive marking on unpossessed inalienable nouns
An inalienable noun carries possessive marking regardless of whether it is possessed or unpossessed

data.field: plant parts, parts of a whole, eggs, a few other things

meta.field: generic human nouns are obligatorily bound/possessed
human nouns must co-occur with another noun (e.g. Hup-man, NonIndian-woman, but *man)

data.field: typically occur with default 3rd person PN

meta.field: Noun compounds created from two noun phrases are common and systematically produced
verb roots can be combined in a single predicate without markers of subordination (distinct from subordinating construction) or distinct inflection
serial verb constructions involve chaining of roots together in one morphophonological word
nominal segment of adjective or verb occurs before the root adjective or verb
nominal segment of adjective or verb occurs after the root adjective or verb
incorporated element is possessed N/body part
nominal segment of adjective or verb can only be a possessed noun or a body part
intransitive verb roots can combine with a nominal segment
There exists in the language only one morpheme that derives a noun from a verb
A morpheme which derives an agent or subject from a verb

data.field: classifier, depends on verb and classifier used

meta.field: A morpheme which derives an instrument from a verb

data.field: classifier, depends on verb and classifier used

meta.field: A morpheme which derives an event from a verb
A morpheme which derives a patient or object from a verb
A morpheme which derives a location from a verb
Any other nominalizers which are not detailed above
A morpheme which derives a verb from an adjective

data.field: no specific morpheme, but TAM inflection may be added to root

meta.field: A morpheme which derives a verb from a noun

data.field: no specific morpheme, but TAM inflection may be added to root

meta.field: A morpheme which derives an adjective from a noun. The result is neutral (not privative, not attributive)
A morpheme which derives an adjective from a noun. The result is an adjective which means that the noun which it modifies lacks the original noun, e.g. English 'fear' and 'fearless'
A morpheme which derives an adjective from a noun. The result is an adjective which means that the noun which it modifies has the original noun, e.g. English 'fear' and 'fearful'
inflectional morphology on verbs only occurs as suffixes
inflectional morphology on verbs only occurs as prefixes

data.field: realized in optional tense-related contrast particles

meta.field: temporal flow' ex: perfective vs imperfective

data.field: not easy to answer, since default 'no-aspect' declarative suffix is the only aspect-less alternative

meta.field: Marking of expected/unexpected action or result
Marking of habilitative (capacity to do something)
inflectional marking of capacity to do something
affect markers (in notes mark whether positive or negative)
social interaction markers (in notes indicate type of interaction)
inflectional marker to indicate activity done in cooperation, independently, etc.
marker expressing motion away from something
Indicates that the action of the predicate is realized in multiple places, multiple times or both
indicates speaker is not responsible for veracicty of statement, merely reporting; 'allegedly'
indicate presence of adjacent representation of repeated discourse
indicates information has been sensed firsthand but not visually (usually heard; also smelled, tasted, felt)
indicates information has been witnessed visually- indicate only if an overt marker
dedicated imperative morpheme or verb form
single morpheme used to signal imperative (command) mood
single morpheme used to signal prohibitive mood (negative command; 'don't do something')

data.field: but does require a distinct neg imp construction type

meta.field: distinct morpheme for polite imperative constructions (specify if it has other functions in the language)

data.field: but polite imperatives often involve applicative and/or perfective aspect markers

meta.field: as opposed to imperative; the person in control of desired state of affairs is not the adressee; ex: 'Let's sing' / 'Let him sing'
single morpheme or verb form to mean '(be careful lest) X happens'
verb agrees (via person marking affixes) with core arguments
distinct 3rd person VCRMS for different genders
number marked separately from VCRMs for some persons
number not encoded in VCRM but seperate sometimes
we inclusive- us and you is distinct form we exclusive- us and not you
expected 3rd subject VCRM morph, but not surface realized
expected 3rd object VCRM morph, but not surface realized
both subject VCRMs and object VCRMs exist
VCRM alignment (e.g. nom-acc, split erg, etc.)
VCRMs align as in case marking?
Possessive markers same as VCRM subject markers
same morphemes used for possessive markers as for VCRMs
Free pronouns show same paradigmatic structure as VCRMs
Free pronouns formed by VCRM + common element
Plural free pronouns formed by singular free pronoun + PL
third person pronouns used as proximate demonstratives
third person pronouns used as definite articles w/ nouns
same pronoun form for subject and object
I.e. same except for case marker; no suppletive forms (if only some suppletion, indicate which forms)
e.g. English 'himself', Spanish 'se'; distinct form(s) from basic (non-reflexive) PNs; distinct from reflexive verbal affix
obligatory marking of gender on animates
if no appropriate classifier exists, noun itself (or some variant) can occur in classifier slot
special classifier forms that occur only with numerals
but are NOT a distinct set of numeral classifiers
classifiers used as derivational suffixes to derive nouns
besides gender, animacy, shape, function (indicate briefly in notes)
case marking of core grammatical relations on core referential NPs
case marking of core GRs on core pronouns
case marking of GRs on oblique referential NPs
case marking of GRs on oblique pronouns
number of distinct oblique case markers

data.field: locative, instrumental, comitative, adlative, ablative functions

meta.field: special case form for calling/addressing someone

data.field: but vocative kin term forms exist

small size; can also indicate affect
large size; can also indicate affect

data.field: form derived from 'big' is exclusively affectual

meta.field: nominal number marking dependent on animacy (e.g. pronoun/human/animal vs. inanimate)
e.g. 'John and his associates', 'John and them'
grammatical form on noun indicating two (specifically)

data.field: verbal perfective, inchoative markers used with nouns
masc/fem classifiers may be used with adult humans

meta.field: four or more term demonstrative system (specify number of distinct terms [roots])
morphological marking on numeral terms themselves

data.field: masc/fem classifiers may be used with adult humans

meta.field: neither prepositions nor postpostions exist in language

data.field: only example is apparently at Port loan

meta.field: VCRMs can attach affixally to adpositions
free pronouns attach or appear near adpositions

data.field: indicate position relative to pronominal referent; e.g. 'inside him'

meta.field: as opposed to 'derived' which have counterparts in other word classes
approximate number of underived adjectives if <50
adjectives agree in gender with head noun
adjectives agree in animacy with head noun
adjectives agree in number with head noun
Possessive phrase composed of a free possessor and its possessum has possessor first (e.g. John's book)
Possessive phrase composed of a free possessor and its possessum has possessum first (e.g. 'book of John')
free pronoun noun possessive construct possible
Possessive phrase can be composed of a free pronoun and its possessum
Cross-reference marker required in possessive constructions (even with referential NP possessor)
Cross-reference marker prohibited in possessive constructions with referential NP possessor
possessive postposition employed in some constructions
Possessive phrase can be created using a postposition, e.g. Spanish 'casa de mi abuela'
basic constituent order (SVO,SOV, not definable, etc.)
Identify basic word order of transitive declarative sentences
If a free NP is an oblique, its grammatical relation is obligatorily marked
more than 1 referential NP per clause possible
It is possible to have more than one referential noun phrase in a transitive sentence
Negation is created syntactically and is not affixed to the verb
Negation is created by attaching a negative morpheme before the root of the verb
Negation is created by attaching a negative morpheme after the root of the verb
form of negation depends on clausal inflection (e.g. realis vs. irrealis)
Clausal inflection such as irrealis versus realis affects the form of negation, e.g. morphological or analytical
distinct negative form for 'NP does not exist'
lexical/phrasal form distinct from 'I know + NEG'
There exist in the language verbs that accompany main verbs of clauses and take grammatical marking not expressed by main verbs.
predicates that are nouns require the copula to be grammatical
predicates that are nouns do not require the copula
predicates that are nouns may have the copula in some instances (e.g. depending on TAM marking, etc.)

data.field: when special TAM marking is present
when special TAM marking is present

meta.field: interrogative words and indefinite pronouns identical
interrogative words and indefinite pronouns related
inversion of subject and verb occurs in polar questions
inversion of subject and verb occurs in content (question-word) questions
include passive formed via verb compounding/serialization
analytical passive construction permits oblique reintroduction of original subject
include causative formed via verb compounding/serialization

data.field: different compounded roots indicate different types of causation

meta.field: RC precedes noun that it modifies
RC follows noun that it modifies
e.g. 'the dog cat chased-NMZR got away' ('the cat that the dog chased got away')
compare Eng 'the one that fell' (but in Eng 'one' could be considered a head)
headless relative clauses are the dominant or only form of RC
I.e. RCs that form a constituent with a head noun (in a single noun phrase) are rare or nonexistent; some descriptions may refer to adjoined or correlative clauses.
relative clause may occur with a noun classifier/class marker
it may be unclear whether the classifier is the nominal head of the construction or is an agreement marker on the RC
morphological relativizer is homophonous with nominalizer
morphological relativizer is homophonous with topic marker (nominal arguments)
e.g. Eng 'the boy who ate the apple'
relative pronouns same as interrogative pronouns
Relativizer/relative pronoun encodes grammatical relation of the head with respect to the verb of the relative clause
e.g. Eng 'he said that he was going' (vs. 'he said, "I'm going"')
special markers to indicate same vs. different subject when two clauses are combined
